questions.text: An ophthalmic image reveals multiple shallow depressions near the limbus, located in the superior part of the cornea, just beneath the upper eyelid. Based on this image finding alone, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Episcleral vessel inflammation without scleral involvement

options.label: B
options.text: Fibrovascular conjunctival growth encroaching onto the cornea

options.label: D
options.text: Deep scleral inflammation extending beyond conjunctiva

questions.correct_answer: C. Post-inflammatory limbal follicular scarring pits
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Post-inflammatory limbal follicular scarring pits

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Herbert pits are diagnostic of previous trachomatous infection and appear as limbal scars due to resolved limbal follicles; they are typically seen in the superior limbus and are not associated with active inflammation.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman with established rheumatoid arthritis has joint pain and swelling. Which joint is most commonly affected in established RA?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Wrist

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The wrist, MCP, and PIP joints are the hallmark locations of RA involvement, especially in chronic disease.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man undergoing cisplatin-based chemotherapy for metastatic lung cancer develops severe nausea and vomiting shortly after treatment. The oncology team initiates antiemetic prophylaxis to control these symptoms. Which of the following medications is the drug of choice for managing this chemotherapy and radiotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Granisetron

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Granisetron, a 5-HT₃ receptor antagonist, is the drug of choice for managing nausea and vomiting associated with chemotherapy and radiotherapy.

questions.text: The shown clinical test is seen in the following swellings except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Sebaceous cyst

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sebaceous cyst does not transilluminate. Cystic hygroma, ranula, and spermatocele transilluminate due to their clear fluid content.
  • ➤ Sebaceous cyst does not transilluminate.
  • ➤ Sebaceous cyst
  • ➤ not
  • ➤ Cystic hygroma, ranula, and spermatocele transilluminate due to their clear fluid content.
  • ➤ Cystic hygroma, ranula, and spermatocele

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the clinical features of Amanita phalloides (Death Cap mushroom) poisoning?

options.label: A
options.text: Immediate gastrointestinal symptoms followed by prolonged cholinergic crisis and seizures

options.label: B
options.text: Delayed gastrointestinal symptoms, temporary improvement, then fulminant hepatic and possible renal failure

options.label: C
options.text: Rapid-onset neurotoxicity with mydriasis, hallucinations, and central anticholinergic syndrome

options.label: D
options.text: Persistent vomiting and diarrhea with complete recovery within 24 hours and no systemic toxicity

questions.correct_answer: B. Delayed gastrointestinal symptoms, temporary improvement, then fulminant hepatic and possible renal failure
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Delayed gastrointestinal symptoms, temporary improvement, then fulminant hepatic and possible renal failure

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Amanita phalloides poisoning follows a triphasic course : initial delayed GI symptoms, a deceptive recovery phase, and eventual fulminant hepatic failure often accompanied by renal dysfunction. Early recognition is critical to initiate aggressive supportive care and consider antidotal therapy (e.g., silibinin).
  • ➤ Amanita phalloides poisoning follows a triphasic course : initial delayed GI symptoms, a deceptive recovery phase, and eventual fulminant hepatic failure often accompanied by renal dysfunction.
  • ➤ triphasic course
  • ➤ fulminant hepatic failure
  • ➤ Early recognition is critical to initiate aggressive supportive care and consider antidotal therapy (e.g., silibinin).

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with pain and swelling just below his left knee. He reports that the pain has been gradually worsening over the past few months, especially after playing basketball and running. On physical examination, there is localized tenderness and swelling over the tibial tuberosity, and the patient experiences pain with active knee extension against resistance. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Osgood-Schlatter disease

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the National Action Plan for Prevention and Control of Snakebite Envenoming (NAP-SE) is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: The plan aims to eliminate snakebite deaths entirely by 2025

options.label: B
options.text: It proposes a 70% reduction in deaths and disability by 2030

options.label: C
options.text: It aims to halve deaths and disability due to snakebites by 2030

options.label: D
options.text: The target year for outcome evaluation is aligned with the 2047 Health@100 vision

questions.correct_answer: C. It aims to halve deaths and disability due to snakebites by 2030
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) It aims to halve deaths and disability due to snakebites by 2030

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The NAP-SE (National Action Plan for Snakebite Envenoming) aims to halve the number of deaths and disability caused by snakebite envenoming in India by the year 2030 , focusing on antivenom access, surveillance, emergency care, and a One Health approach.
  • ➤ NAP-SE (National Action Plan for Snakebite Envenoming)
  • ➤ halve
  • ➤ by the year 2030

questions.text: A 70-year-old male presents to OPD with severe cachexia and dysphagia to solids. Endoscopy shows a lumen-occluding growth at the mid-esophagus. While he is being investigated, you start him on TPN. After one day, the patient gets seizures and tetany. What likely abnormality is responsible for the above event?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Hypophosphatemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The sudden onset of seizures and tetany in a patient who has just started on TPN is most likely due to hypophosphatemia, a key feature of refeeding syndrome, which requires careful management and monitoring of electrolyte levels during the initiation of nutrition in malnourished patients.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding colostrum compared to mature breast milk is true?

options.label: A
options.text: Colostrum has lower protein content than mature milk

options.label: B
options.text: Colostrum has higher fat content than mature milk

options.label: C
options.text: Colostrum is richer in immunoglobulin A (IgA) than mature milk

options.label: D
options.text: Colostrum has higher lactose concentration than mature milk

questions.correct_answer: C. Colostrum is richer in immunoglobulin A (IgA) than mature milk
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Colostrum is richer in immunoglobulin A (IgA) than mature milk

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Colostrum, the early milk produced postpartum, is rich in immunoglobulin A (IgA), providing essential mucosal immunity to the newborn.

questions.text: Match the following Brodmann areas with their corresponding functional cortical regions:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) A–2, B–3, C–1, D–4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Area 4 → Primary motor cortex (precentral gyrus): Responsible for voluntary movements Area 6 → Premotor cortex and supplementary motor area: Involved in motor planning Areas 41, 42 → Primary auditory cortex (superior temporal gyrus) Area 17 → Primary visual cortex (calcarine cortex in occipital lobe)

  • ➤ Area 6 → Premotor cortex and supplementary motor area: Involved in motor planning
  • ➤ Area 6 → Premotor cortex and supplementary motor area:
  • ➤ Areas 41, 42 → Primary auditory cortex (superior temporal gyrus)
  • ➤ Areas 41, 42 → Primary auditory cortex (superior temporal gyrus)

  • ➤ Area 17 → Primary visual cortex (calcarine cortex in occipital lobe)

questions.text: A 63-year-old male with a history of chronic heart failure presents for routine follow-up. He reports some improvement in exertional dyspnea but continues to experience episodes of angina pectoris. His current therapy includes a beta-blocker and a loop diuretic. A drug is added that inhibits both neprilysin and angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE), leading to vasodilation and reduced cardiac workload. After a few weeks, he develops hypotension and angioedema. Which of the following agents was most likely prescribed?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Omapatrilat

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Omapatrilat is a dual inhibitor of neprilysin and ACE that lowers cardiac workload via vasodilation but is associated with a high risk of angioedema due to bradykinin accumulation.

questions.text: Which of the following labeled muscles in the diagram performs extension of knee and flexion of hip joint?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) A

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Among the four muscles that make up the quadriceps femoris group , only the rectus femoris crosses both the hip and knee joints , allowing it to perform hip flexion in addition to knee extension . The other three (vastus medialis, vastus intermedius, and vastus lateralis) are confined to knee extension.
  • ➤ Among the four muscles that make up the quadriceps femoris group , only the rectus femoris crosses both the hip and knee joints , allowing it to perform hip flexion in addition to knee extension .
  • ➤ quadriceps femoris group
  • ➤ rectus femoris
  • ➤ hip and knee joints
  • ➤ hip flexion
  • ➤ knee extension
  • ➤ The other three (vastus medialis, vastus intermedius, and vastus lateralis) are confined to knee extension.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman with Stage 4 lung cancer presents with bilateral leg weakness, incontinence, and numbness below the umbilicus. Examination shows hyperreflexia and decreased anal tone. What is the most appropriate immediate step?

options.label: D
options.text: Start LMWH for suspected spinal thrombosis

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Start intravenous dexamethasone

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In suspected cord compression, give IV corticosteroids immediately to prevent permanent neurologic damage.

questions.text: Which of these is incorrect about the procedure shown in the image?

options.label: A
options.text: It can be done for superficial wounds

options.label: B
options.text: It derives nutrition from the recipient bed

options.label: C
options.text: It is used after oral malignancy for reconstruction

options.label: D
options.text: It can be used to cover large wounds

questions.correct_answer: C. It is used after oral malignancy for reconstruction
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) It is used after oral malignancy for reconstruction

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ STSGs are not typically used for oral malignancy reconstruction; flaps are preferred. STSGs work for superficial wounds , derive nutrition from the recipient bed, and cover large wounds effectively .
  • ➤ STSGs are not typically used for oral malignancy reconstruction; flaps are preferred.
  • ➤ not
  • ➤ STSGs work for superficial wounds , derive nutrition from the recipient bed, and cover large wounds effectively .

  • ➤ large wounds effectively

questions.text: During beta-oxidation of fatty acids in peroxisomes, which of the following is the final product formed as a result of the metabolic breakdown?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Octanoyl CoA

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Peroxisomal beta-oxidation of very long-chain fatty acids ends with the formation of medium-chain fatty acyl-CoAs , most notably octanoyl CoA , which are then transferred to mitochondria for further oxidation.
  • ➤ Peroxisomal beta-oxidation
  • ➤ medium-chain fatty acyl-CoAs
  • ➤ octanoyl CoA

questions.text: A metabolic deficiency leads to impairment in a primary pathway, which in turn causes a secondary defect due to the deficiency of one of its key substrates. Which of the following correctly identifies the primary pathway affected and the secondary pathway compromised as a result?

options.label: A
options.text: Pentose phosphate pathway, fatty acid synthesis

options.label: B
options.text: Pentose phosphate pathway, fatty acid oxidation

options.label: C
options.text: Citric acid cycle, Pentose phosphate pathway

questions.correct_answer: A. Pentose phosphate pathway, fatty acid synthesis
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Pentose phosphate pathway, fatty acid synthesis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A deficiency in the pentose phosphate pathway leads to decreased NADPH , which secondarily impairs fatty acid synthesis , a pathway that requires NADPH as a reducing equivalent .
  • ➤ deficiency in the pentose phosphate pathway
  • ➤ decreased NADPH
  • ➤ fatty acid synthesis
  • ➤ NADPH as a reducing equivalent

questions.text: A 67-year-old man with prior myocardial infarction presents with dizziness. On exam, he has a regular wide-complex tachycardia at 170/min. ECG is shown below. Which of the following findings suggests supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) with aberrancy rather than a ventricular tachycardia (VT)?

options.label: A
options.text: No R wave in lead aVR

options.label: C
options.text: Monomorphic R wave pattern in precordial leads V1–V6

options.label: D
options.text: Structural heart disease seen on prior studies

questions.correct_answer: A. No R wave in lead aVR
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) No R wave in lead aVR

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ ECG clues like absence of dominant R in aVR may favor SVT. Presence of AV dissociation and structural heart disease suggest VT.
  • ➤ ECG clues like absence of dominant R in aVR may favor SVT.
  • ➤ Presence of AV dissociation and structural heart disease suggest VT.

questions.text: Match the Growth Factor Receptors with Their Functions: Choose the correct matching:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) A–3, B–1, C–2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ ERBB2 [HER2/neu] is an epidermal growth factor receptor , RET is a neural growth factor receptor , and KIT is a stem cell growth factor receptor —understanding these associations is essential for recognizing molecular mechanisms in cancer biology.
  • ➤ ERBB2 [HER2/neu] is an epidermal growth factor receptor
  • ➤ RET is a neural growth factor receptor
  • ➤ KIT is a stem cell growth factor receptor

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with a 6-month history of bloating and chronic diarrhea. She denies recent travel, antibiotic use, or sick contacts. Physical examination reveals a mildly distended abdomen. On dermatologic examination, there are clustered vesicular lesions on the extensor surfaces of her elbows and knees. A skin biopsy shows IgA deposition at the tips of the dermal papillae. An upper endoscopy with duodenal biopsy reveals villous atrophy and crypt hyperplasia. The patient is started on a gluten-free diet, after which her symptoms and rash resolve. Which of the following best describes the pathogenesis of her disease?

options.label: A
options.text: Antibody-mediated IgG attack on enterocytes triggered by gluten exposure

options.label: B
options.text: Direct cytotoxic effects of gliadin on intestinal epithelial cells

options.label: C
options.text: Delayed hypersensitivity reaction mediated by MHC class I molecules and CD8+ T cells

options.label: D
options.text: Helper T-cell–mediated damage following gliadin presentation via MHC class II molecules

questions.correct_answer: D. Helper T-cell–mediated damage following gliadin presentation via MHC class II molecules
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Helper T-cell–mediated damage following gliadin presentation via MHC class II molecules

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Celiac disease is triggered by gliadin , the immunogenic component of gluten. Deamidated gliadin is presented via MHC class II molecules, leading to CD4+ T-cell–mediated mucosal damage . The condition is associated with HLA-DQ2/DQ8 and may present with dermatitis herpetiformis due to IgA deposition at the dermal papillae .
  • ➤ Celiac disease is triggered by gliadin , the immunogenic component of gluten. Deamidated gliadin is presented via MHC class II molecules, leading to CD4+ T-cell–mediated mucosal damage .
  • ➤ Celiac disease
  • ➤ gliadin
  • ➤ Deamidated gliadin
  • ➤ MHC class II
  • ➤ CD4+ T-cell–mediated mucosal damage
  • ➤ The condition is associated with HLA-DQ2/DQ8 and may present with dermatitis herpetiformis due to IgA deposition at the dermal papillae .
  • ➤ HLA-DQ2/DQ8
  • ➤ dermatitis herpetiformis
  • ➤ IgA deposition
  • ➤ dermal papillae

questions.text: A 30-year-old man diagnosed with schizophrenia is being evaluated for long-term antipsychotic treatment. He has a strong family history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and dyslipidemia, and he expresses concern about weight gain and metabolic side effects associated with psychiatric medications. Which of the following antipsychotic agents is least likely to cause metabolic adverse effects such as weight gain, hyperglycemia, or dyslipidemia?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Ziprasidone

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ziprasidone and Aripiprazole are the antipsychotic agent least associated with metabolic side effects such as weight gain and dyslipidemia, making it a suitable option in patients at risk for metabolic syndrome.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is evaluated for exercise-induced muscle cramps, fatigue, and myoglobinuria. He reports symptoms starting after short bursts of physical activity. Lab findings reveal elevated serum CK, myoglobin in urine, and hemolytic anemia. Further analysis identifies a deficiency in an enzyme involved in glycolysis, specifically affecting skeletal muscle and erythrocytes. Which of the following enzymes is most likely deficient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Phosphofructokinase-1

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tarui’s disease (GSD VII) results from phosphofructokinase-1 deficiency , leading to impaired glycolysis in skeletal muscle and red blood cells , manifesting as exercise-induced cramps , myoglobinuria , and hemolytic anemia .
  • ➤ Tarui’s disease (GSD VII)
  • ➤ phosphofructokinase-1 deficiency
  • ➤ glycolysis in skeletal muscle and red blood cells
  • ➤ exercise-induced cramps
  • ➤ myoglobinuria
  • ➤ hemolytic anemia

questions.text: All of these are true regarding decubitus ulcers except?

options.label: A
options.text: Anemia and malnutrition contribute to its development

options.label: B
options.text: The most common site is the heel

options.label: C
options.text: A bedsore can be expected if erythema appears that does not change color on pressure

questions.correct_answer: B. The most common site is the heel
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) The most common site is the heel

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most common site for decubitus ulcers is over the ischial tuberosity, not the heel, and management often requires regular repositioning, use of pressure-distributing devices, and optimizing the local environment for wound healing.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents to the emergency department with fever, agitation, and hydrophobia. He reports being bitten by a stray dog 3 weeks ago and did not receive post-exposure prophylaxis. Rabies is suspected. Which of the following diagnostic methods is most appropriate for demonstration of rabies antigen in a living patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Virus isolation in cell culture from cerebrospinal fluid

options.label: B
options.text: Immunofluorescence assay of corneal smear or nape of neck skin biopsy

options.label: C
options.text: Detection of rabies antibody in serum

options.label: D
options.text: Identification of Negri bodies on brain biopsy

questions.correct_answer: B. Immunofluorescence assay of corneal smear or nape of neck skin biopsy
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Immunofluorescence assay of corneal smear or nape of neck skin biopsy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Immunofluorescence staining of corneal epithelial cells or nape of neck skin biopsy is a key ante-mortem diagnostic method for detecting rabies virus antigen in living patients.

questions.text: A 62-year-old postmenopausal woman is diagnosed with advanced endometrial carcinoma that has progressed despite first-line chemotherapy. Molecular profiling of the tumor reveals microsatellite instability-high (MSI-H) status. Her oncologist considers immunotherapy as a second-line option. Which of the following immune checkpoint inhibitors is FDA-approved for use in such advanced endometrial cancer cases?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Pembrolizumab

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pembrolizumab is the FDA-approved PD-1 inhibitor for advanced endometrial cancer, especially in tumors with microsatellite instability or mismatch repair deficiency.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the CDC classification of bioterrorism agents is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: Melioidosis is a Category B threat due to its low human-to-human transmissibility and potential environmental persistence

options.label: B
options.text: Nipah virus is Category C due to its emerging status and potential for genetic engineering

options.label: C
options.text: Clostridium perfringens is Category A due to its alpha-toxin and gastrointestinal outbreaks

options.label: D
options.text: Ricin toxin is Category B due to its potential for use as an aerosolizable toxin

questions.correct_answer: C. Clostridium perfringens is Category A due to its alpha-toxin and gastrointestinal outbreaks
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Clostridium perfringens is Category A due to its alpha-toxin and gastrointestinal outbreaks

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Clostridium perfringens is a Category B agent, not Category A . Only agents like Anthrax, Botulism, Plague, Tularemia, Smallpox , and viral hemorrhagic fevers are in Category A , posing the highest risk to national security due to their potential for mass transmission and mortality.
  • ➤ Clostridium perfringens is a Category B agent, not Category A .
  • ➤ Clostridium perfringens
  • ➤ Category B
  • ➤ not Category A
  • ➤ Only agents like Anthrax, Botulism, Plague, Tularemia, Smallpox , and viral hemorrhagic fevers are in Category A , posing the highest risk to national security due to their potential for mass transmission and mortality.
  • ➤ Anthrax, Botulism, Plague, Tularemia, Smallpox
  • ➤ viral hemorrhagic fevers
  • ➤ Category A
  • ➤ highest risk to national security

questions.text: A 74-year-old man with uncontrolled diabetes complains of foot and ankle pain interfering with work. He stands all day at a factory and seeks relief. Which medication is most suitable for his painful neuropathy?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Duloxetine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Duloxetine is preferred for diabetic neuropathy in elderly due to its efficacy and lower adverse effect profile compared to TCAs.

questions.text: At what minimum endometrial thickness should an endometrial biopsy be considered to rule out endometrial malignancy in a postmenopausal patient with abnormal uterine bleeding?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 4 mm

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In postmenopausal women with abnormal uterine bleeding, an endometrial thickness of ≥4 mm on transvaginal ultrasound warrants endometrial biopsy to rule out malignancy.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl has the following skinfold thickness values at 4 sites: 14 mm, 12 mm, 13 mm, and 11 mm. What is the clinical interpretation regarding obesity using SFT (Skinfold Thickness) guidelines?

options.label: B
options.text: Obese, since any one site > 12 mm

questions.correct_answer: C. Obese, since total is ≥ 50 mm
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Obese, since total is ≥ 50 mm

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In adolescent girls, a sum of skinfold thickness ≥ 50 mm (measured across mid-triceps, biceps, subscapular, and suprailiac regions) is diagnostic of obesity . Accurate measurement and site selection are essential for proper clinical interpretation.
  • ➤ In adolescent girls, a sum of skinfold thickness ≥ 50 mm (measured across mid-triceps, biceps, subscapular, and suprailiac regions) is diagnostic of obesity .
  • ➤ sum of skinfold thickness ≥ 50 mm
  • ➤ obesity
  • ➤ Accurate measurement and site selection are essential for proper clinical interpretation.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Receiver Operating Characteristic (ROC) curves are incorrect? A test with an AUC (Area Under Curve) of 0.5 performs no better than chance. AUC values >1 indicate perfect diagnostic accuracy. ROC curve is independent of disease prevalence. ROC curve plots Specificity vs. (1 - Sensitivity).
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 2 and 4 only

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ ROC curves are powerful tools to evaluate diagnostic accuracy independent of disease prevalence. The Area Under the Curve (AUC) ranges from 0.5 (chance) to 1.0 (perfect). ROC plots use sensitivity and 1-specificity, not specificity or prevalence.

questions.text: Which of the following are absolute contraindications to administering regional anesthesia? Patient refusal Platelet count < 70,000 Localized skin infection at the injection site Raised intracranial pressure with midline shift Uncorrected Hypovolemic shock
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) All of the above

  • ➤ Uncorrected hypovolemia/shock

questions.text: Which of the following is classified as a microvascular complication of diabetes mellitus?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Macular edema

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Microvascular complications of diabetes include retinopathy (macular edema), nephropathy, and neuropathy due to small vessel damage.

questions.text: In a meta-analysis, a forest plot reveals that one large study significantly influences the pooled effect estimate, resulting in a narrow confidence interval. What does this narrow confidence interval primarily indicate?

options.label: A
options.text: High heterogeneity among the included studies

options.label: B
options.text: Low risk of bias across all included studies

options.label: C
options.text: Increased precision due to the substantial weight of the large study

options.label: D
options.text: Overestimation of the effect size due to random error

questions.correct_answer: C. Increased precision due to the substantial weight of the large study
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Increased precision due to the substantial weight of the large study

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In meta-analyses, a narrow confidence interval around the pooled effect estimate often reflects increased precision, commonly due to the significant weight of a large study. This emphasizes the importance of considering study sizes and their influence on the overall results when interpreting forest plots.
  • ➤ In meta-analyses, a narrow confidence interval around the pooled effect estimate often reflects increased precision, commonly due to the significant weight of a large study.
  • ➤ This emphasizes the importance of considering study sizes and their influence on the overall results when interpreting forest plots.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric neurology clinic by his parents due to progressive difficulty walking and frequent falls. His parents report that he used to be physically active but now has worsening balance issues. Neurologic examination reveals gait ataxia, loss of vibratory sense and proprioception, muscle weakness in the lower extremities, and absent deep tendon reflexes. An echocardiogram is performed as part of the workup and shows hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. Genetic testing reveals an autosomal recessive disorder involving an expanded GAA trinucleotide repeat in a gene. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Friedreich ataxia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Friedreich ataxia is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by GAA trinucleotide repeat expansion in the frataxin gene , leading to degeneration of the cerebellum and spinal cord , ataxia , loss of vibratory sense , muscle weakness , areflexia , and hypertrophic cardiomyopathy . It presents in early childhood , and affected patients are typically wheelchair-bound within a few years .
  • ➤ Friedreich ataxia is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by GAA trinucleotide repeat expansion in the frataxin gene , leading to degeneration of the cerebellum and spinal cord , ataxia , loss of vibratory sense , muscle weakness , areflexia , and hypertrophic cardiomyopathy .
  • ➤ Friedreich ataxia
  • ➤ autosomal recessive disorder
  • ➤ GAA trinucleotide repeat expansion in the frataxin gene
  • ➤ degeneration of the cerebellum and spinal cord
  • ➤ ataxia
  • ➤ loss of vibratory sense
  • ➤ muscle weakness
  • ➤ areflexia
  • ➤ hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
  • ➤ It presents in early childhood , and affected patients are typically wheelchair-bound within a few years .
  • ➤ early childhood
  • ➤ wheelchair-bound within a few years

questions.text: Fibropeptidase A and B are characterized by a highly negative charge. This property is primarily due to the presence of which of the following amino acids?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Glutamate and Aspartate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Glutamate and Aspartate , due to their acidic side chains , are responsible for the highly negative charge seen in fibropeptidase A and B , a property crucial to their biological function .
  • ➤ Glutamate
  • ➤ Aspartate
  • ➤ acidic side chains
  • ➤ highly negative charge

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Eosinophilic Granuloma are true? The hallmark of diagnosis includes Langerhans cells on biopsy with eosinophilic infiltrate , and immunohistochemical staining positive for CD1a and S100 .

  • ➤ immunohistochemical staining positive for CD1a and S100

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding otitis media with effusion (OME) and acute otitis media (AOM/ASOM) are true? In ASOM, "light house sign" or pulsatile otorrhoea is a hallmark of tympanic membrane perforation. In OME, pain is a common presenting complaint due to active infection and inflammation. The most common organisms implicated in ASOM are Streptococcus pneumoniae and Haemophilus influenzae. Grommet insertion through myringotomy is commonly performed in OME for permanent drainage. The most common site for myringotomy is the anterosuperior quadrant of the tympanic membrane.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 1, 3, 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The "light house sign," which refers to pulsating discharge through a tympanic membrane perforation, is a characteristic feature seen during the suppurative stage of acute suppurative otitis media (ASOM). In contrast, otitis media with effusion (OME) is a non-infective condition marked by sterile fluid accumulation behind the tympanic membrane, typically without associated pain or inflammation. Streptococcus pneumoniae and Haemophilus influenzae are the most commonly implicated pathogens in ASOM. For chronic or recurrent OME, grommet insertion via myringotomy is a standard therapeutic approach. Importantly, myringotomy is usually performed in the anteroinferior quadrant of the tympanic membrane to ensure optimal drainage and avoid injury to important middle ear structures.
  • ➤ The "light house sign," which refers to pulsating discharge through a tympanic membrane perforation, is a characteristic feature seen during the suppurative stage of acute suppurative otitis media (ASOM).
  • ➤ In contrast, otitis media with effusion (OME) is a non-infective condition marked by sterile fluid accumulation behind the tympanic membrane, typically without associated pain or inflammation.
  • ➤ Streptococcus pneumoniae and Haemophilus influenzae are the most commonly implicated pathogens in ASOM.
  • ➤ For chronic or recurrent OME, grommet insertion via myringotomy is a standard therapeutic approach.
  • ➤ Importantly, myringotomy is usually performed in the anteroinferior quadrant of the tympanic membrane to ensure optimal drainage and avoid injury to important middle ear structures.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Marrack’s Lattice Hypothesis are incorrect? questions.text: A clinical instructor is discussing the biochemistry of metabolism with a medical student during a case review of a patient suspected of having a nutritional deficiency. The instructor asks the student to identify which reaction within the citric acid cycle requires thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP) as a coenzyme.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) α–ketoglutarate → Succinyl CoA

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP), the active form of vitamin B1, is a crucial coenzyme in Oxidative decarboxylation of Alpha Keto Acid. In the citric acid cycle, TPP is specifically required for the α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase complex, which catalyzes the conversion of α-ketoglutarate to succinyl CoA. This is mechanistically similar to the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex (converting pyruvate to acetyl CoA), which also requires TPP. Thiamine deficiency can therefore impair these critical energy-producing pathways, contributing to conditions like beriberi and Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome.
  • ➤ Thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP), the active form of vitamin B1, is a crucial coenzyme in Oxidative decarboxylation of Alpha Keto Acid.
  • ➤ In the citric acid cycle, TPP is specifically required for the α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase complex, which catalyzes the conversion of α-ketoglutarate to succinyl CoA.
  • ➤ This is mechanistically similar to the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex (converting pyruvate to acetyl CoA), which also requires TPP.
  • ➤ Thiamine deficiency can therefore impair these critical energy-producing pathways, contributing to conditions like beriberi and Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the Mapleson F circuit are correct? It is a modification of the Ayre’s T-piece and includes a reservoir bag. It does not have an expiratory valve and fresh gas flow rate is 2-3 times the minute ventilation in spontaneous ventilation.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 1, 2 and 4 only

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ The Mapleson F (Jackson-Rees) circuit is a pediatric-friendly breathing system used in both spontaneous and controlled ventilation. It is important to recognize its structure, uses, and limitations—especially the lack of expiratory valves and implications for gas scavenging.

questions.text: A 52-year-old postmenopausal woman presents with complaints of persistent foul-smelling vaginal discharge and irregular per vaginal bleeding for 4 months. Pelvic examination reveals a large exophytic cervical mass extending to the lower third of the vagina. MRI shows involvement of adjacent parametrial tissues, and PET-CT reveals metastasis to para-aortic lymph nodes without evidence of distant organ metastasis. Both kidneys appear normal on imaging. What is the FIGO 2018 stage of cervical carcinoma in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Stage III C2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ FIGO Stage IIIC2 cervical cancer indicates involvement of para-aortic lymph nodes , which can be detected through imaging (CT, PET-CT, MRI) or pathology. It is a key determinant for prognosis and treatment planning, even when pelvic organs or parametria are not grossly involved. Distinction between pelvic node (IIIC1) and para-aortic node (IIIC2) metastasis is crucial for staging and therapeutic approach.
  • ➤ FIGO Stage IIIC2 cervical cancer indicates involvement of para-aortic lymph nodes , which can be detected through imaging (CT, PET-CT, MRI) or pathology.
  • ➤ FIGO Stage IIIC2 cervical cancer
  • ➤ para-aortic lymph nodes
  • ➤ It is a key determinant for prognosis and treatment planning, even when pelvic organs or parametria are not grossly involved.
  • ➤ Distinction between pelvic node (IIIC1) and para-aortic node (IIIC2) metastasis is crucial for staging and therapeutic approach.

  • ➤ para-aortic node

questions.text: A 35-year-old immunocompromised man presents with progressive neurological decline. MRI of the brain reveals white matter changes, and CSF PCR detects a polyomavirus. In reviewing CNS infections, which of the following statements is incorrect?

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: D

questions.correct_answer: D. Cytomegalovirus causes bilateral temporal lobe hemorrhagic infarction

questions.text: Match the following clinical findings with their diagnosis. Clinical findings: Delayed passage of Meconium Red currant Jelly Stools Peri anal rash with acidic stools Metabolic alkalosis with paradoxical aciduria Diagnosis: Intussusception Infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis Hirschsprungs disease Lactose intolerance
questions.explanation:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Delayed meconium suggests Hirschsprung’s, red currant jelly stools point to intussusception, acidic stool rash indicates lactose intolerance, and metabolic alkalosis with paradoxical aciduria is classic for infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis.

questions.text: For a sensory nerve fiber that is connected to a Pacinian corpuscle located on the palmar surface of the right hand, the first synapse in the corresponding sensory pathway occurs at which of the following locations?

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The dorsal column–medial lemniscus pathway conveys fine touch, vibration, and proprioception from the body. For upper limb sensations like those from Pacinian corpuscles in the right hand , the first synapse occurs in the ipsilateral dorsal column nuclei (nucleus cuneatus) in the medulla , not the spinal cord.

questions.text: A 47-year-old man presents to the emergency department with right upper quadrant pain and fatigue. He reports frequent episodes of binge drinking, especially on weekends. Physical examination reveals tender hepatomegaly. Laboratory studies show: AST: 248 U/L ALT: 104 U/L Total bilirubin: Mildly elevated Alkaline phosphatase: Slightly elevated Ultrasound shows a heavy, greasy liver. Findings from the Liver biopsy is given in the image below. Which of the following best explains the mechanism of liver injury in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Hepatocyte necrosis due to iron overload and hemosiderin deposition

options.label: B
options.text: Autoimmune-mediated destruction of intrahepatic bile ducts

options.label: C
options.text: Acetaldehyde-induced injury with formation of Mallory bodies and inflammation

options.label: D
options.text: Cholesterol crystal deposition triggering granulomatous inflammation

questions.correct_answer: C. Acetaldehyde-induced injury with formation of Mallory bodies and inflammation
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Acetaldehyde-induced injury with formation of Mallory bodies and inflammation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Alcoholic hepatitis occurs due to acetaldehyde-mediated injury to hepatocytes, leading to Mallory body formation , necrosis , and inflammation . It typically follows binge drinking , presents with painful hepatomegaly and AST > ALT , and is a component of alcohol-related liver disease .
  • ➤ Alcoholic hepatitis occurs due to acetaldehyde-mediated injury to hepatocytes, leading to Mallory body formation , necrosis , and inflammation .

  • ➤ acetaldehyde-mediated injury
  • ➤ Mallory body formation
  • ➤ necrosis
  • ➤ inflammation
  • ➤ It typically follows binge drinking , presents with painful hepatomegaly and AST > ALT , and is a component of alcohol-related liver disease .
  • ➤ binge drinking
  • ➤ painful hepatomegaly
  • ➤ AST > ALT
  • ➤ alcohol-related liver disease

questions.text: A 61-year-old man with a 40-pack-year smoking history presents with right calf pain that occurs during walking and is relieved by rest. He denies swelling, redness, or trauma to the leg. On examination, there are diminished right dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses, and the skin appears cool but intact. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial investigation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Arterial Doppler

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Arterial Doppler with ankle-brachial index is the first-line investigation for suspected peripheral arterial disease presenting with intermittent claudication.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with progressive swelling of the lower limb for the past five years. Examination shows non-pitting edema. The skin over the dorsum of the toes cannot be pinched. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Chronic lymphedema

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chronic lymphedema presents with progressive, non-pitting edema, buffalo hump deformity of the foot, square toes, and a positive Stemmer’s sign due to subcutaneous fibrosis.

questions.text: An infant is brought to the emergency department with signs of neonatal sepsis. Blood cultures yield a Gram-positive cocci forming β-hemolytic colonies on blood agar. The organism is resistant to bacitracin and demonstrates a positive CAMP test. Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Streptococcus agalactiae

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Streptococcus agalactiae (Group B Streptococcus) is a common cause of neonatal sepsis and is identified by β-hemolysis, bacitracin resistance, and a positive CAMP test.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman undergoes a radical mastectomy with extensive axillary dissection. Postoperatively, she presents with difficulty pushing against a wall and is noted to have scapular winging on physical examination. Injury to which of the following nerves is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) C

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The long thoracic nerve innervates the serratus anterior muscle, which stabilizes the scapula against the thoracic wall. Injury to this nerve during procedures such as axillary dissection can result in scapular winging, a characteristic clinical finding.
  • ➤ The long thoracic nerve innervates the serratus anterior muscle, which stabilizes the scapula against the thoracic wall.
  • ➤ Injury to this nerve during procedures such as axillary dissection can result in scapular winging, a characteristic clinical finding.

questions.text: A 2.5 kg baby born through LSCS cried immediately after birth. On the routine visit pediatrician noticed that baby has macroglossia with hemihypertrophy of limbs. What is your best possible diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Beckwith–Wiedemann syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Beckwith–Wiedemann syndrome presents with macroglossia, hemihypertrophy, and neonatal hypoglycemia, and carries a risk of embryonal tumors such as Wilms tumor.
  • ➤ macroglossia, hemihypertrophy, and neonatal hypoglycemia,

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presents to the clinic with knee pain after a football injury. He reports that he was tackled and twisted his knee while it was planted on the ground. On physical examination, there is significant swelling around the knee joint, along with instability when performing the Lachman test. The patient also experiences pain and restricted motion when attempting to extend the knee. Based on the clinical findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Ans. A) O’Donoghue triad

questions.text: A woman in her third pregnancy is in the second stage of labor, which has lasted for two hours. She has adequate uterine contractions, and on examination, the cervix is fully dilated. The fetal head is at station 0, with 2+ molding and 2+ caput succedaneum noted. The sagittal suture lies in the right occipito-transverse position, and the fetal heart rate is 140 beats per minute. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: C
options.text: Wait for an hour for spontaneous labor

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Lower segment cesarean section

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In women with prolonged second-stage labor, station 0, moulding and caput, and failure of fetal head rotation, the appropriate management is lower segment cesarean section.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman with severe suicidal depression is being considered for electroconvulsive therapy (ECT). questions.text: What is the most likely indication for the use of this cream?

questions.text: A 60-year-old man reports epigastric pain relieved by meals. His doctor suspects H. pylori and plans noninvasive testing. Which of the following statement is correct regarding H. pylori diagnostics in clinical practice?

questions.text: A 42-year-old man visits a pharmacy in India to purchase a medication for hypertension. The pharmacist informs him that the drug is a prescription-only medication and cannot be dispensed without a valid doctor’s prescription. Under which of the following drug schedules is this medication most likely classified as per Indian drug regulations?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Schedule H

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In India, Schedule H drugs are classified as prescription-only medications and can be dispensed only with a valid medical prescription.

questions.text: Match the following: Column A (Mallampati Class) Class I Class II Class III Class IV Column B (Visible Structures) Soft palate, fauces, uvula visible Soft palate and fauces seen, tip of uvula not visible Soft palate, hard palate visible Soft palate not visible

questions.text: In a Nutritional Rehabilitation Center (NRC), a child previously admitted with Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM) is now clinically alert, free from major complications, and ready to begin energy-dense feeding. At which intervention phase is the child currently placed?

questions.text: In the anatomical arrangement of intermuscular spaces such as the cubital fossa, femoral triangle, anatomical snuff box, etc., what primarily forms the roof of these spaces? Skin Superficial fascia Subcutaneous fat, cutaneous nerves and vessels Deep fascia

  • ➤ subcutaneous
  • ➤ fat
  • ➤ cutaneous nerves
  • ➤ vessels,

questions.text: A 6-year-old child is brought to the pediatric clinic with complaints of restlessness at night and intense itching around the anal area, especially during the night. The parents report seeing the child scratching the perianal region frequently, and he appears irritable with disturbed sleep. What is the most likely causative organism responsible for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Enterobius vermicularis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Enterobius vermicularis (pinworm) causes intense perianal pruritus, especially at night, due to deposition of eggs around the anus, and is diagnosed using the scotch tape test.

questions.text: A 9-week pregnant woman presents with a request for pregnancy termination. On evaluation, she is found to be hemodynamically stable with no contraindications to available medical or surgical options. A first-trimester medical termination is planned. Which of the following is not an appropriate method for terminating pregnancy during the first trimester?
questions.correct_answer: D. Extra-amniotic instillation of ethacridine lactate
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Extra-amniotic instillation of ethacridine lactate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Extra-amniotic instillation of ethacridine lactate is inappropriate for first-trimester pregnancy termination and is used for second-trimester MTP due to its delayed onset of action.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman presents to the emergency department following a motor vehicle collision. She did not sustain any serious physical injuries, but she appears drowsy and states that she is feeling very sleepy. Emergency medical staff collected several open medication bottles from the floor of her automobile. Although the contents of two of the bottles could not be determined, the patient's recently filled bottle of diazepam was almost empty. The patient quickly becomes unresponsive and stops breathing. Administration of which of the following agents will reverse these symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Flumazenil

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Flumazenil is the appropriate reversal agent for benzodiazepine overdose. Flumazenil works by competitively inhibiting benzodiazepines at their binding site on the GABA-A receptor, which can reverse the central nervous system depressant effects of benzodiazepines, including sedation and respiratory depression. It is crucial to choose the specific antidote based on the type of drug overdose to effectively reverse the symptoms.
  • ➤ Flumazenil is the appropriate reversal agent for benzodiazepine overdose.
  • ➤ Flumazenil works by competitively inhibiting benzodiazepines at their binding site on the GABA-A receptor, which can reverse the central nervous system depressant effects of benzodiazepines, including sedation and respiratory depression.
  • ➤ It is crucial to choose the specific antidote based on the type of drug overdose to effectively reverse the symptoms.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after a high-speed motor vehicle collision. He was found unresponsive at the scene with no signs of external bleeding. On arrival, he is in extremis, and resuscitative efforts are initiated. Despite immediate intervention, he succumbs to his injuries within minutes. Based on trauma-related causes of early mortality, which of the following injuries is most likely to result in the most rapid death if not promptly addressed?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Airway injury

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Airway injury is the most rapidly fatal traumatic injury, as complete airway obstruction can lead to death within minutes unless prompt airway management is performed.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents with progressive painless proptosis of the right eye for the past 3 months. He also complains of occasional double vision and a sense of pressure in the orbit. There is no history of trauma. On examination, there is non-tender fullness in the superonasal quadrant of the orbit with downward and lateral displacement of the globe. An axial CT image is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Ethmoidal mucocele

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ethmoidal mucocele commonly presents with non-axial proptosis , diplopia , and a history of chronic sinus pathology . CT typically shows an expansile, homogenous lesion causing orbital displacement.
  • ➤ Ethmoidal mucocele commonly presents with non-axial proptosis , diplopia , and a history of chronic sinus pathology .
  • ➤ Ethmoidal mucocele
  • ➤ non-axial proptosis
  • ➤ diplopia
  • ➤ history of chronic sinus pathology
  • ➤ CT typically shows an expansile, homogenous lesion causing orbital displacement.

questions.text: A researcher is investigating a potential link between a newly discovered chemical contaminant in groundwater and the occurrence of congenital anomalies in a rural population. To establish a relationship, particularly focusing on the temporality aspect of Hill’s criteria, which of the following study designs would be the most appropriate?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Concurrent cohort study

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Temporality is the most essential Hill’s criterion for causality. It is best established through prospective cohort studies , where the exposure is observed before the outcome occurs.
  • ➤ Temporality is the most essential Hill’s criterion
  • ➤ prospective cohort studies
  • ➤ exposure is observed before the outcome

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman is being assessed due to a history of multiple consecutive pregnancy losses. A recent pelvic ultrasound raises suspicion of a Müllerian anomaly. She is otherwise healthy with regular menstrual cycles and no prior history of pelvic surgery. Which of the following is the best method to confirm the suspected diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Hysteroscopy + Laparoscopy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The combination of hysteroscopy and laparoscopy is the gold standard for confirming Müllerian anomalies, particularly in patients with recurrent pregnancy loss.

questions.text: Match the Following: Column A – Diagnostic Test Casoni’s test Schick test Patch test Dick’s test Column B – Disease Detected Streptococcal infection Hydatid disease Diphtheria susceptibility Filariasis
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) A–2, B–3, C–4, D–1

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Each hypersensitivity skin test has specific diagnostic or epidemiological significance: Casoni's for hydatid disease, Schick for diphtheria, Patch for filariasis, and Dick's for streptococcal toxin response.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to her gynecologist with complaints of vaginal discharge and a fishy odor. After taking a history and performing a pelvic examination, a wet mount preparation shows a "clue cell" pattern. The pH of the vaginal fluid is found to be above 4.5. The diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis is made. Which of the following is the recommended first-line treatment for bacterial vaginosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Metronidazole

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Metronidazole is the first-line treatment for bacterial vaginosis, which presents with vaginal pH > 4.5, clue cells, and fishy odor.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman with primary progressive MS has had multiple relapses despite interferon β therapy. Which monoclonal antibody is best suited for her?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Ocrelizumab

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ocrelizumab is approved for both RRMS and PPMS and is highly effective in reducing progression and relapse frequency.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with a complaint of post-coital bleeding. A Pap smear result is positive, indicating possible cervical epithelial abnormality. She has no significant prior gynecologic interventions. What is the next appropriate step in management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Colposcopy directed biopsy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Colposcopy with directed biopsy is the next step after a positive Pap smear, particularly in women with symptoms such as post-coital bleeding, to confirm the presence and grade of cervical pathology.

questions.text: A 64-year-old hospitalized patient develops fever, leukocytosis, and purulent sputum after 7 days of mechanical ventilation. Culture of tracheal aspirate reveals Pseudomonas aeruginosa, known for its intrinsic resistance mechanisms and limited treatment options. The medical team is reviewing antibiotic choices. Which of the following agents is not appropriate for treating Pseudomonas infections?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Vancomycin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vancomycin lacks activity against gram-negative bacteria such as Pseudomonas aeruginosa and is not used in its treatment.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man with sickle cell disease presents with fever, severe chest pain, limb pain. Oxygen saturation is 84% on room air. Chest X-ray is shown below. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding his condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Chronic HU therapy should be considered

options.label: B
options.text: He is experiencing acute chest syndrome

options.label: D
options.text: Maintaining Hct above 30% is part of acute management

questions.correct_answer: C. Daily sildenafil improves pulmonary hemodynamics
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Daily sildenafil improves pulmonary hemodynamics

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acute chest syndrome is a leading cause of morbidity in sickle cell disease and requires urgent supportive care, transfusion, and long-term hydroxyurea therapy. Sildenafil is not recommended.
  • ➤ Acute chest syndrome is a leading cause of morbidity in sickle cell disease and requires urgent supportive care, transfusion, and long-term hydroxyurea therapy.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman with hypertension presents after a routine visit reveals 5.4 g/day proteinuria. Biopsy of the kidney is shown below. Similar changes were seen in 45% of glomeruli at the corticomedullary junction. What is the most likely diagnosis?

questions.text: A 32-year-old man from Uttar Pradesh presents with intermittent fever, progressive pallor, and massive hepatosplenomegaly. Laboratory tests show pancytopenia. questions.text: During a terrorist bomb attack, a victim taking shelter behind a concrete wall still sustains tympanic membrane rupture and pulmonary contusions. Which phenomenon best explains the injury despite shielding?

options.label: A
options.text: Mass blast wind displacing the wall

options.label: B
options.text: Reflection and wrapping of the blast wave around barriers

options.label: C
options.text: Projectiles from wall fragmentation causing secondary trauma

options.label: D
options.text: Seismic transmission of shock via ground vibration

questions.correct_answer: B. Reflection and wrapping of the blast wave around barriers
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Reflection and wrapping of the blast wave around barriers

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Primary blast injuries are caused by the pressure wave itself , not flying debris or collapse. Blast waves can wrap around barriers and injure people behind cover . Tympanic membrane rupture and blast lung are hallmark primary blast injuries — indicating that pressure effects reached the victim despite apparent shelter.
  • ➤ Primary blast injuries are caused by the pressure wave itself , not flying debris or collapse.
  • ➤ Primary blast injuries
  • ➤ pressure wave itself
  • ➤ Blast waves can wrap around barriers and injure people behind cover .
  • ➤ Blast waves
  • ➤ wrap around barriers
  • ➤ injure people behind cover
  • ➤ Tympanic membrane rupture and blast lung are hallmark primary blast injuries — indicating that pressure effects reached the victim despite apparent shelter.
  • ➤ Tympanic membrane rupture
  • ➤ blast lung
  • ➤ primary blast injuries

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with continuous leakage of urine following a prolonged and complicated vaginal delivery two weeks ago. On physical examination and further imaging, she is found to have a genitourinary fistula. She is managed conservatively with continuous bladder drainage using a Foley catheter. Which of the following characteristics is most associated with increased likelihood of spontaneous closure of the fistula under this conservative approach?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: The catheter is maintained for at least 8 weeks

options.label: C
options.text: The fistula measures 2 to 3 mm in diameter

options.label: D
options.text: The fistula is associated with pelvic radiation

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) The fistula measures 2 to 3 mm in diameter

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Small fistulas (2–3 mm) following obstetric trauma have the highest likelihood of spontaneous closure with continuous bladder drainage using a Foley catheter.

questions.text: Calculate my ponderal index-I am 1200 grams and length of 42 cm and also tell me which type it fits into?

questions.text: An ASHA conducts postnatal visits on Days 3, 7, 14, 21, and 28 for a newborn delivered in a health facility. She misses the 42nd-day visit. Is she eligible for the HBPNC incentive?

options.label: A

questions.text: Which one of the following definitions is incorrect?

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with fluctuating eyelid drooping that worsens throughout the day. He also reports difficulty moving his eyes in multiple directions. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the likely diagnosis?

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the closure of fetal circulatory structures are correct? The ductus venosus functionally closes after the removal of the placenta and anatomically closes by 7 days. The foramen ovale undergoes functional closure at birth due to pressure changes after breathing is initiated and anatomically closes by 21 days. The ductus arteriosus functionally closes within 10–15 hours and anatomically closes within 10–21 days. Anatomical closure of the foramen ovale may take several months to years.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 1, 3, 4 only

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fetal circulatory structures such as the ductus venosus , foramen ovale , and ductus arteriosus undergo functional closure soon after birth due to physiological changes such as the removal of placental circulation and initiation of pulmonary respiration. Anatomical closure , however, takes a variable amount of time: from days (ductus venosus, ductus arteriosus) to months or even years (foramen ovale), which is important in understanding normal adaptation and potential congenital anomalies.
  • ➤ Fetal circulatory structures such as the ductus venosus , foramen ovale , and ductus arteriosus undergo functional closure soon after birth due to physiological changes such as the removal of placental circulation and initiation of pulmonary respiration.
  • ➤ ductus venosus
  • ➤ foramen ovale
  • ➤ ductus arteriosus
  • ➤ functional closure soon after birth
  • ➤ Anatomical closure , however, takes a variable amount of time: from days (ductus venosus, ductus arteriosus) to months or even years (foramen ovale), which is important in understanding normal adaptation and potential congenital anomalies.
  • ➤ Anatomical closure

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding cells marked in the image below are correct? They are flask-shaped and located in a single layer within the Purkinje cell layer of the cerebellar cortex. The axons of the cells form the only efferent output from the cerebellar cortex and terminate in cerebellar or vestibular nuclei. Each of these cells gives rise to a single axon that enters the white matter after crossing the granular layer. The dendrites of these cells do not enter the molecular layer. These cells are excitatory and release glutamate as their primary neurotransmitter.
questions.explanation:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Purkinje cells are inhibitory GABAergic neurons of the cerebellar cortex. They form a single output line from the cortex, with axons projecting to the cerebellar or vestibular nuclei. These flask-shaped cells have extensive dendritic trees in the molecular layer and serve as a critical relay in motor coordination and cerebellar function.
  • ➤ Purkinje cells are inhibitory GABAergic neurons of the cerebellar cortex.

  • ➤ They form a single output line from the cortex, with axons projecting to the cerebellar or vestibular nuclei.
  • ➤ single output line
  • ➤ These flask-shaped cells have extensive dendritic trees in the molecular layer and serve as a critical relay in motor coordination and cerebellar function.
  • ➤ dendritic trees
  • ➤ molecular layer

questions.text: A 61-year-old man with a 6-year history of open-angle glaucoma presents for a routine follow-up. He has been on latanoprost monotherapy since diagnosis. questions.text: A patient with a history of gallstones is now presenting with jaundice and right upper quadrant pain. Which imaging modality is considered most reliable for diagnosing Mirizzi syndrome?

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mirizzi syndrome is a rare condition in which gallstones become impacted in the cystic duct or neck of the gallbladder, leading to compression of the common bile duct. This results in obstructive jaundice. Imaging modalities like ultrasound , CT , and particularly MRCP are crucial for diagnosis. MRCP provides detailed visualization of the biliary tree, identifying stones, ductal compression, and other abnormalities.
  • ➤ Mirizzi syndrome is a rare condition in which gallstones become impacted in the cystic duct or neck of the gallbladder, leading to compression of the common bile duct.

questions.text: A mother brings her 8-month-old child Saheli for a routine visit. She complaints that her child is having chronic diarrhoea for more than a month and has failure to thrive. questions.text: Which of the following structures in the kidney acts as a countercurrent multiplier?

options.text: Thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle

In contrast, the vasa recta preserves this gradient through passive exchange, acting as the countercurrent exchanger . This division is crucial for interpreting renal concentrating defects and diuretic mechanisms.

questions.text: A hospital lab is reviewing the clinical utility of Real-Time PCR-based viral load testing in different patient populations. For which of the following infections is quantitative viral load monitoring by PCR not routinely useful or necessary for diagnosis or therapeutic monitoring?

questions.text: A viral sample from a child with fever, conjunctivitis, cough, and a spreading maculopapular rash is inoculated into cell culture. questions.text: A 29-year-old woman diagnosed with pulmonary tuberculosis is started on standard antitubercular therapy including rifampicin.
